awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Uncovering Quantitative Design Principles of RNA Regulators For Synthetic Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description: Cells have an amazing ability to process information, make decisions, and change their state in response to changing environments. This ability is encoded within the cellular DNA genome, which is converted into RNA and protein molecules through the basic processes of gene expression. Among the many functions these RNAs and proteins perform is regulating their own expression. In fact RNAs are now known to regulate almost all aspects of gene expression, and play central roles in controlling some of life's most basic processes. A key question in biotechnology and synthetic biology is then: How can RNA molecules be designed to control the expression of target genes inside cells to facilitate applications ranging from using cells as chemical factories all the way to using them as environmental sensors? As with many biomolecules, RNA function is intimately related to its structure. In this work, the investigator builds off of his development of a new small synthetic RNA mechanism called Small Transcription Activating RNAs, or STARs. STARs are hypothesized to allow the construction of unique gene expression control techniques since they represent a brand new function for sRNAs. This project seeks to use STARs as a test-bed for uncovering the principles for engineering RNA molecules to precisely control gene expression inside cells. This work will help realize the potential of RNA as a powerful substrate for cellular engineering. It will also shed new light on our scientific understanding of the fundamental sequence/structure/function relationship that underlies RNA's central role in natural biological systems. The projected studies and research training activities are thus expected to have a broad impact on society, ranging from the science of cellular gene regulation and the engineering science of RNA gene regulation that can directly connect to a broad array of biotechnological applications. This project will also cultivate the next generation of highly trained graduate students and teachers of synthetic biology who will be introduced to the broad, interdisciplinary nature of biotechnology research. Moreover, this program will actively engage the broader community to help create an informed public that is equipped to make important decisions about the future of synthetic biology.

Technical Description:  The overall goal of this project is to build an integrated research and education program focused on uncovering quantitative design principles that link small RNA sequence, structure, and function, and to use these principles to design synthetic RNAs that can precisely regulate gene expression. The education plan focuses on integrating research into the training of the next generation of synthetic biology students and teachers, and informing and exciting the broader public about synthetic biology.

Trans-acting bacterial small RNAs (sRNA) exert regulation via direct RNA-RNA interactions with target messenger RNAs (mRNAs) that cause structural changes in the target. These changes in turn regulate many aspects of gene expression including transcription, translation and mRNA degradation. The central hypotheses of this project are that: 1) quantitative sRNA structure/function design principles can be discovered and used to rationally optimize and expand the functionality of RNA regulators, and 2) circuit-level design rules can be discovered and used to engineer new synthetic RNA genetic modules that control the timing and pattern of gene expression. The central goal of this CAREER project is to use Small Transcription Activating RNAs (STARs) as a test-bed for uncovering the quantitative design principles of RNA regulators for synthetic biology. This will be pursued using a multi-faceted approach that includes using cutting-edge RNA structure measurement technologies to elucidate the molecular level design principles of STARs. Once molecular-level principles are learned, the project will focus on using these techniques to learn the design rules for integrating STARs into decision making regulatory networks. In addition, new experiments and computational tools that can quantitatively model the kinetics of gene expression mediated by STARs will be used to understand how different aspects of STAR function propagate through RNA networks. Successful completion of these studies will forward the broader goal of creating a quantitative discipline of biological design that can be used to program cellular systems to solve important problems in sustainable energy, and biomanufacturing.  In addition, the work may provide insight to mechanisms of native small RNA regulation of naturally occurring biological systems.

Educational activities include developing a long term plan for the continuation of the Cold Spring Harbor Synthetic Biology summer course as a training center for a broad range of students and teachers across the globe; developing quantitative curricular materials for training future generations of synthetic biologists; and performing hands-on activities aimed towards families with school-age children to excite and inform them about synthetic biology.

por.por_cntn:
Microorganisms display broad and fascinating functions, including the ability to sense and respond to constantly changing environmental conditions, and the ability to produce diverse chemical compounds such as fuels, foods and pharmaceuticals from sustainable feedstocks. The field of synthetic biology aims to understand, reuse, and repurpose these functions of natural biological systems to develop technologies that address pressing societal challenges. At the core of many of the functions of natural organisms is gene expression - converting the instructions stored within the organism's genome into proteins that perform tasks within the cell. The functions of natural organisms are defined by the genes involved in that function, and there are many mechanisms by which cells can turn the right genes on at the right time, and in just the right amount, to give rise to diverse functions. A central molecular player in the control of gene expression is RNA, the close chemical cousin of DNA that can both store genetic information, like DNA, as well as perform cellular functions, like proteins. Therefore, the central research goal of this work was to uncover the principles by which RNAs control gene expression in microbes, and use this knowledge to create new RNA systems that can be used in impactful biotechnologies. The central educational goal was to integrate the research into new education platforms for synthetic biology that can help fuel the growing bioeconomy.

This grant supported projects that led to nineteen different publications, in a range of journals including ACS Synthetic Biology, Annual Reviews of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Nature Communications, Nature Chemical Biology, Nature Nanotechnology, and Nature Biotechnology. Key components of the intellectual merit of this work include the discovery of fundamental knowledge of how RNA molecules function in cells, the use of this knowledge to develop new RNA based mechanisms that can turn on or off gene expression in bacterial cells like molecular light switches, and the development of computer models of these RNA systems that can be used to further understand their function and inform how they can be used in engineered biological systems. These discoveries applied to bacteria were also used to uncover new knowledge about how RNA molecules function to control gene expression in mammalian systems.

The fundamental principles of RNA molecules learned also directly led to a number of impactful technology applications, including the invention of a new molecular system that uses these engineered RNAs to control the expression of enzymes in engineered microbial cells that can convert sugars into important chemical compounds such as anti-cancer drug precursors. The understanding of these engineered RNA systems also directly led to the creation of new 'cell free' diagnostic technologies that repurpose natural protein systems that allow microorganisms to detect contaminants in their environment, and genetically rewire them so that they work in test tubes - completely free of living bacteria. These so called 'cell-free synthetic biology' reactions can then be freeze dried in test tubes (using the same process as making astronaut ice cream) which allows them to be stored on the shelf or easily transported to where they are needed. In the field, a user simply adds a drop of water to the tube to test the water for the presence of the contaminants. With this approach, we created a suite of diagnostic technologies that can detect plant pathogens, toxic metals, naturally abundant toxins, and consumer waste byproducts that contribute to the pollution of our water supplies.

The broader impacts of this work are significant, with this work contributing to a number of other important areas in both education and outreach. For education, this work directly contributed to the development of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Summer Course in Synthetic Biology, a hands on training environment that has brought together hundreds of trainees and synthetic biology experts to help shape the directions of the field. The graduate courses in synthetic biology fueled by this work also directly lead to the creation of the first National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) in Synthetic Biology, which includes courses, workshops, mentorship and experiential learning components to provide a wholistic training platform for the next generation of synthetic biologists. A critical component of this work has been the direct mentorship of trainees including undergraduates, graduates and post-docs. Trainees supported by this grant have gone onto prestigious graduate schools and post-doctoral positions, have taken research positions in the biotechnology industry, are CEOs of synthetic biology startup companies, and are faculty at leading research institutions. This work has also directly touched the broader public, with features in several high profile news outlets geared towards the general public, including a feature in NSF's Discovery Files (https://www.nsf.gov/news/mmg/mmg_disp.jsp?med_id=186632&from) and Scientific American (https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/dna-finds-pollutants-in-green-glowing-water-test/).

Overall this work demonstrated that fundamental investigations to understand how RNA molecules control gene expression in nature lead to impactful biotechnologies that address important societal challenges.
